elements.content: Two ethylenediamine-pillared zinc hydroxysulfates related as subcell, Zn4SO4(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5·3H2O, and supercell, [Zn4SO4(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5]7·18H2O, the zinc analogues of Co4SO4(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5·3H2O, were prepared and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The subcell−supercell relation is described. The analysis of hydrogen bonds and cavities were conducted, suggesting the existence of subcell−supercell to be due to a strong correlation between the organic pillars, the interlayer guests, and groups decorating the inorganic layers. Reversible dehydration−rehydration behavior on the subcell is demonstrated via thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text: Two ethylenediamine-pillared zinc hydroxysulfates related as subcell, Zn4SO4(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5⋅3H2O, and supercell, [Zn4SO4(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5]7⋅18H2O, the zinc analogues of Co4SO4(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5⋅3H2O, were prepared and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The subcell-supercell relation is described. The analysis of hydrogen bonds and cavities were conducted, suggesting the existence of subcell-supercell to be due to a strong correlation between the organic pillars, the interlayer guests, and groups decorating the inorganic layers. Reversible dehydration-rehydration behavior on the subcell is demonstrated via thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Two ethylenediamine-pillared zinc hydroxysulfates related as subcell and supercell were prepared and characterized. The detailed structural responses to the order−disorder feature and distribution of guest molecules, intergallery water desorption, and resorption were fully analyzed.
elements.clean_text: Two ethylenediamine-pillared zinc hydroxysulfates related as subcell and supercell were prepared and characterized. The detailed structural responses to the order-disorder feature and distribution of guest molecules, intergallery water desorption, and resorption were fully analyzed.

elements.content: The concept of using organic spacers in the design and synthesis of organic/inorganic hybrid materials has been widely acknowledged by the virtue of advantages over conventional materials. Pillared layered materials are one among those currently of interest. These microporous materials have considerable chemical and structural diversity, having developed from pillared clays to layered materials such as phosphonates, phosphates, oxyhalides, and hydroxides.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The concept of using organic spacers in the design and synthesis of organic/inorganic hybrid materials has been widely acknowledged by the virtue of advantages over conventional materials. Pillared layered materials are one among those currently of interest. These microporous materials have considerable chemical and structural diversity, having developed from pillared clays to layered materials such as phosphonates, phosphates, oxyhalides, and hydroxides.

elements.content: We have previously demonstrated that ethylenediamine (en) can be used as a pillaring agent to separate cobalt hydroxysulfate layers by the synthesis of Co4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5·3H2O (CSEN). CSEN adopts a structure in which layers of edge-sharing octahedra are decorated by tetrahedral CoII and sulfate units, and linked by coordination of the en to the apical sites of CoII tetrahedra in adjacent layers (Figure ). Here we report the preparation and characterization of related en-pillared zinc hydroxysulfates of which the presence of subcell and supercell is addressed. The relationship between these phases to the synthetic basic zinc sulfates and the mineral Namuwite is also described.
elements.clean_text: We have previously demonstrated that ethylenediamine (en) can be used as a pillaring agent to separate cobalt hydroxysulfate layers by the synthesis of Co4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5⋅3H2O (CSEN). CSEN adopts a structure in which layers of edge-sharing octahedra are decorated by tetrahedral CoII and sulfate units, and linked by coordination of the en to the apical sites of CoII tetrahedra in adjacent layers (Figure ). Here we report the preparation and characterization of related en-pillared zinc hydroxysulfates of which the presence of subcell and supercell is addressed. The relationship between these phases to the synthetic basic zinc sulfates and the mineral Namuwite is also described.

elements.content: Perspective view of the pillared tetrahedral−octahedral−tetrahedral (T−O−T) structure adopted by en-pillared metal(II) hydroxysulfates.
elements.clean_text: 1  Perspective view of the pillared tetrahedral-octahedral-tetrahedral (T-O-T) structure adopted by en-pillared metal(II) hydroxysulfates.

elements.content: Hydrothermal Syntheses. Four sets of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (98% Aldrich) aqueous solutions and concentrated sulfuric acid (98% Aldrich) in a mole ratio of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O/H2SO4/H2O 1:1:100 were prepared. The en (99% Aldrich) in 0.20, 0.16, 0.13, 0.10 molar proportion to Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was added to the solutions labeled hereafter as reaction 1 to 4, respectively. The reactions were conducted under autogenous pressure in a hydrothermal bomb with a 70% filling factor at 180 °C over 3 days. The solid products were recovered by filtration followed by washing and rinsing with deionized water and acetone, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

 Hydrothermal Syntheses. Four sets of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98% Aldrich) aqueous solutions and concentrated sulfuric acid (98% Aldrich) in a mole ratio of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O/H2SO4/H2O 1:1:100 were prepared. The en (99% Aldrich) in 0.20, 0.16, 0.13, 0.10 molar proportion to Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was added to the solutions labeled hereafter as reaction 1 to 4, respectively. The reactions were conducted under autogenous pressure in a hydrothermal bomb with a 70% filling factor at 180 °C over 3 days. The solid products were recovered by filtration followed by washing and rinsing with deionized water and acetone, respectively.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. The products were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction using a STOE Stadi-P X-ray powder diffractometer equipped with a linear position-sensitive detector (PSD) and curved quartz monochromator giving Cu Kα 1 radiation (λ = 1.54060 Å). In-situ X-ray diffraction experiments were also carried out on the same diffractometer equipped with a furnace in the case of ZNEN1, in the temperature range 50 ≤ T (°C) ≤ 400 under a helium flow and an hour interval at each temperature for data collection.
elements.clean_text: X-ray Crystallography. The products were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction using a STOE Stadi-P X-ray powder diffractometer equipped with a linear position-sensitive detector (PSD) and curved quartz monochromator giving Cu Kα 1 radiation (λ = 1.54060 Å). In-situ X-ray diffraction experiments were also carried out on the same diffractometer equipped with a furnace in the case of ZNEN1, in the temperature range 50 ≤ T (°C) ≤ 400 under a helium flow and an hour interval at each temperature for data collection.

elements.content: The data collections on single crystals of Zn4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5·3H2O (ZNEN1) and [Zn4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5]7·18H2O (ZNEN4), from reaction 1 and 4, respectively, were conducted at the UK Synchrotron Radiation Source (SRS) at Daresbury Laboratories Station 9.8 using a Bruker AXS Smart CCD diffractometer equipped with silicon 111 monochromator and Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream at 150(2) K. An absorption correction was applied using SADABS-Brucker Area Detector Absorption Correction.
elements.clean_text: The data collections on single crystals of Zn4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5⋅3H2O (ZNEN1) and [Zn4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5]7⋅18H2O (ZNEN4), from reaction 1 and 4, respectively, were conducted at the UK Synchrotron Radiation Source (SRS) at Daresbury Laboratories Station 9.8 using a Bruker AXS Smart CCD diffractometer equipped with silicon 111 monochromator and Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream at 150(2) K. An absorption correction was applied using SADABS-Brucker Area Detector Absorption Correction.

TG/DTA-MS Analysis. Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis-mass spectroscopic (TG/DTA-MS) data for ZNEN1 were collected on a Seiko SII-TG/DTA 6300 instrument equipped with a Hiden HPR 20 RGA mass spectrometer. Thermal decomposition was studied over the temperature range 20 ≤ T (°C) ≤ 800 at a heating rate of 2 °C min-1 under a flow of helium.
elements.clean_text: TG/DTA-MS Analysis. Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis-mass spectroscopic (TG/DTA-MS) data for ZNEN1 were collected on a Seiko SII-TG/DTA 6300 instrument equipped with a Hiden HPR 20 RGA mass spectrometer. Thermal decomposition was studied over the temperature range 20 ≤ T (°C) ≤ 800 at a heating rate of 2 °C min-1 under a flow of helium.

elements.content: Preparation and Characterization of Rehydrated ZNEN1. The rehydrated single-crystal samples of ZNEN1 were prepared under TG/DTA-MS using a water-saturated helium flow on cooling the sample, holding at 190 °C for 30 min where the fully dehydrated phase was obtained, to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C min-1, followed by 2 h at room temperature. The resulting samples were employed in single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements conducted on the Stoe-IPDS at both 293(2) and 150(2) K using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation.
elements.clean_text: Preparation and Characterization of Rehydrated ZNEN1. The rehydrated single-crystal samples of ZNEN1 were prepared under TG/DTA-MS using a water-saturated helium flow on cooling the sample, holding at 190 °C for 30 min where the fully dehydrated phase was obtained, to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C min-1, followed by 2 h at room temperature. The resulting samples were employed in single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements conducted on the Stoe-IPDS at both 293(2) and 150(2) K using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation.

elements.content: The structures of all crystals studied, i.e., ZNEN1, ZNEN4, and rehydrated ZNEN1, were solved and refined using direct methods followed by successive difference Fourier methods and final full-matrix refinements were against F 2 (STOE X-STEP32 software suite including the supporting programs SHELX-97).
elements.clean_text: The structures of all crystals studied, i.e., ZNEN1, ZNEN4, and rehydrated ZNEN1, were solved and refined using direct methods followed by successive difference Fourier methods and final full-matrix refinements were against F 2 (STOE X-STEP32 software suite including the supporting programs SHELX-97).

elements.content: Vibrational Spectroscopy. Mid-IR (4000−400 cm-1) vibrational spectra of ZNEN1 were obtained from ground single crystals prepared as both Nujol and Fluorolube mulls. The experiments were performed on a Nicolet Magna − IR 560 spectrometer with a resolution of 0.50 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: Vibrational Spectroscopy. Mid-IR (4000-400 cm-1) vibrational spectra of ZNEN1 were obtained from ground single crystals prepared as both Nujol and Fluorolube mulls. The experiments were performed on a Nicolet Magna - IR 560 spectrometer with a resolution of 0.50 cm-1.

elements.content: Hydrothermal Synthesis. The reactions afforded two distinct phases as identified by single-crystal X-ray crystallography ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 from reactions 1 and 4, respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of corresponding products are summarized in Figure compared with simulated powder patterns calculated from the single-crystal data. The pH of the initial reaction mixtures are also denoted in Figure showing the decreasing with the lowering of the en concentration. The calculated patterns of ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 are noticeably alike, and hence the presence of subcell and supercell cannot be noticed from the powder diffraction patterns. Every reflection in the powder pattern collected from the product of reaction 1 was consistent with the simulated pattern of ZNEN1, and indexed in P3̄ giving refined cell parameters a = 8.3256(15), c = 10.6034(16) Å, V = 636.50(22) Å3, suggesting that there was no crystalline impurity and the chosen single crystal was representative of the bulk material. The elemental analysis is also consistent with monophasic Zn4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5·2.8H2O:  calc. (%) C 2.22, H 2.91, N 2.59, S 5.93, Zn 48.42; obs. (%) C 2.25, H 2.72, N 2.50, S 5.54, Zn 46.53. It should be noted that the crystals of ZNEN4 were scarcely found from reaction 4, which was evidentially multiphasic. The structure of ZNEN4 is consequently deduced solely from the single-crystal data. Contrary to reaction 1 and reaction 4, there were no crystals found from reactions 2 and 3, which show similar powder X-ray diffraction patterns identified as a mixture of ZnSO4·xH2O, ZnSO3·xH2O, Zn2SO4(OH)2·xH2O, and Zn(OH)2.
elements.clean_text:
Results

 Hydrothermal Synthesis. The reactions afforded two distinct phases as identified by single-crystal X-ray crystallography ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 from reactions 1 and 4, respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of corresponding products are summarized in Figure  compared with simulated powder patterns calculated from the single-crystal data. The pH of the initial reaction mixtures are also denoted in Figure  showing the decreasing with the lowering of the en concentration. The calculated patterns of ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 are noticeably alike, and hence the presence of subcell and supercell cannot be noticed from the powder diffraction patterns. Every reflection in the powder pattern collected from the product of reaction 1 was consistent with the simulated pattern of ZNEN1, and indexed in P3̄ giving refined cell parameters a = 8.3256(15), c = 10.6034(16) Å, V = 636.50(22) Å3, suggesting that there was no crystalline impurity and the chosen single crystal was representative of the bulk material. The elemental analysis is also consistent with monophasic Zn4(SO4)(OH)6(C2N2H8)0.5⋅2.8H2O: calc. (%) C 2.22, H 2.91, N 2.59, S 5.93, Zn 48.42; obs. (%) C 2.25, H 2.72, N 2.50, S 5.54, Zn 46.53. It should be noted that the crystals of ZNEN4 were scarcely found from reaction 4, which was evidentially multiphasic. The structure of ZNEN4 is consequently deduced solely from the single-crystal data. Contrary to reaction 1 and reaction 4, there were no crystals found from reactions 2 and 3, which show similar powder X-ray diffraction patterns identified as a mixture of ZnSO4⋅xH2O, ZnSO3⋅xH2O, Zn2SO4(OH)2⋅xH2O, and Zn(OH)2.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns for products from reaction 1 to 4 compared with simulated patterns of ZNEN1 and ZNEN4, with the measured pH of the reaction mixtures noted.
elements.clean_text: 2  Powder X-ray diffraction patterns for products from reaction 1 to 4 compared with simulated patterns of ZNEN1 and ZNEN4, with the measured pH of the reaction mixtures noted.

elements.content: Structural Characterization for ZNEN1 and ZNEN4. Crystallographic data for ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 are summarized in Table , with asymmetric units derived from the synchrotron data shown in Figure panels a and c, respectively. The crystal structure of ZNEN1 was deduced in P3̄, and the refinement demonstrated the adoption of the same pillared layered structure as that of CSEN (Figure ) with the layer composition of Zn°3SO4(OH)4·ZnT(OH)2, when Zn° and ZnT denote zinc in octahedral and tetrahedral site, respectively. The calculated free dimensions of the channel opening are 2.0 × 2.6 Å3 with solvent accessible volume of 15.1%. ZNEN1 contains a similar hydrogen-bonding network to that of CSEN13 (Table S1, Supporting Information) classified into four types of interactions; pillar−guest, host−guest, host−host and pillar−host. The resemblance of the hydrogen-bonding network in ZNEN1 to that of CSEN accounts for the observation of the same AAA stacking sequence in both phases.
elements.clean_text: Structural Characterization for ZNEN1 and ZNEN4. Crystallographic data for ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 are summarized in Table , with asymmetric units derived from the synchrotron data shown in Figure  panels a and c, respectively. The crystal structure of ZNEN1 was deduced in P3̄, and the refinement demonstrated the adoption of the same pillared layered structure as that of CSEN (Figure ) with the layer composition of Zn°3SO4(OH)4⋅ZnT(OH)2, when Zn° and ZnT denote zinc in octahedral and tetrahedral site, respectively. The calculated free dimensions of the channel opening are 2.0 × 2.6 Å3 with solvent accessible volume of 15.1%. ZNEN1 contains a similar hydrogen-bonding network to that of CSEN13 (Table S1, Supporting Information) classified into four types of interactions; pillar-guest, host-guest, host-host and pillar-host. The resemblance of the hydrogen-bonding network  in ZNEN1 to that of CSEN accounts for the observation of the same AAA stacking sequence in both phases.

elements.content: Asymmetric units of (a) ZNEN1, (b) rehydrated ZNEN1 shown with 70% thermal ellipsoids, and (c) ZNEN4 with 95% thermal ellipsoids; only part of the numbering scheme is given for ZNEN4 for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Asymmetric units of (a) ZNEN1, (b) rehydrated ZNEN1 shown with 70% thermal ellipsoids, and (c) ZNEN4 with 95% thermal ellipsoids; only part of the numbering scheme is given for ZNEN4 for clarity.

elements.content: The structure of ZNEN4 was solved and refined in the same space group as ZNEN1 with a cell expansion in both a and b directions. Attempts to solve the structure based on the original smaller cell (ZNEN1) led to unstable refinement, as well as unacceptably high residue factors and goodness of fit. The refined structure of ZNEN4 (Table S2, Supporting Information) revealed three crystallographically distinct sulfate groups. Two (S(1) and S(2)) are located in a general position and one (S(3)) is on the 3-fold axis, and so equivalent to the sulfate group found in the ZNEN1 case. The ratio of S(1)/S(2)/S(3) present in the unit cell is 6:6:2.
elements.clean_text: The structure of ZNEN4 was solved and refined in the same space group as ZNEN1 with a   cell expansion in both a and b directions. Attempts to solve the structure based on the original smaller cell (ZNEN1) led to unstable refinement, as well as unacceptably high residue factors and goodness of fit. The refined structure of ZNEN4 (Table S2, Supporting Information) revealed three crystallographically distinct sulfate groups. Two (S(1) and S(2)) are located in a general position and one (S(3)) is on the 3-fold axis, and so equivalent to the sulfate group found in the ZNEN1 case. The ratio of S(1)/S(2)/S(3) present in the unit cell is 6:6:2.

elements.content: Two en units, one of which is disordered (N(1)−C(2)−C(2)*−N(1)*) and the other ordered (N(3)−C(4)−C(5)−N(6)), are also distinguished with the ratio of the disordered to ordered existing in the unit cell of 1:6. The nitrogen (N(1)) and carbon (C(2)) atoms of the disordered en were refined with the C(2)−C(2)* bond length restrained to be equal to those of the ordered motif C(4)−C(5). Unconstrained refinement resulted in an unacceptably long C(2)−C(2)* interatomic distance. Six distinct intergallery water oxygen atoms, O(25) to O(30), and 10 distinct zinc sites, were located in the asymmetric unit with the same ZnT(Zn(1)−Zn(3)):Zn°(Zn(4)−Zn(10)) ratio of 1:3, found for ZNEN1 case.
elements.clean_text: Two en units, one of which is disordered (N(1)-C(2)-C(2)*-N(1)*) and the other ordered (N(3)-C(4)-C(5)-N(6)), are also distinguished with the ratio of the disordered to ordered existing in the unit cell of 1:6. The nitrogen (N(1)) and carbon (C(2)) atoms of the disordered en were refined with the C(2)-C(2)* bond length restrained to be equal to those of the ordered motif C(4)-C(5). Unconstrained refinement resulted in an unacceptably long C(2)-C(2)* interatomic distance. Six distinct intergallery water oxygen atoms, O(25) to O(30), and 10 distinct zinc sites, were located in the asymmetric unit with the same ZnT(Zn(1)-Zn(3)):Zn°(Zn(4)-Zn(10)) ratio of 1:3, found for ZNEN1 case.

elements.content: The different Zn° and ZnT sites in the ZNEN4 structure have similar geometries (Table S3, Supporting Information) with comparable mean interatomic distances (Table ). The mean bond length of ZnT−O is in good agreement with the bond lengths observed for other tetrahedrally coordinated zinc ions in phosphate-based frameworks; 1.95(1) Å in NaH(ZnPO4)2, 1.95(2) and 1.94(1) Å in ZnCa(HPO3)2(H2O)2 and ZnSr(HPO3)2(H2O)2, respectively. The Zn°−O(H) mean bond length is slightly shorter than those found in framework Zn°−O(H); 2.13(1) Å in RbZn2(HPO4)2(H2PO4)·2H2O. There are no comparative literature examples of ZnT−O and Zn°−O(H) in sulfate frameworks. The substantial shortening of Zn°−O(H) compared to Zn°−O(SO3) is partly a result of the unprotonated nature of the latter.
elements.clean_text: The different Zn° and ZnT sites in the ZNEN4 structure have similar geometries (Table S3, Supporting Information) with comparable mean interatomic distances (Table ). The mean bond length of ZnT-O is in good agreement with the bond lengths observed for other tetrahedrally coordinated zinc ions in phosphate-based frameworks; 1.95(1) Å in NaH(ZnPO4)2, 1.95(2) and 1.94(1) Å in ZnCa(HPO3)2(H2O)2 and ZnSr(HPO3)2(H2O)2, respectively. The Zn°-O(H) mean bond length is slightly shorter than those found in framework Zn°-O(H); 2.13(1) Å in RbZn2(HPO4)2(H2PO4)⋅2H2O. There are no comparative literature examples of ZnT-O and Zn°-O(H) in sulfate frameworks. The substantial shortening of Zn°-O(H) compared to Zn°-O(SO3) is partly a result of the unprotonated nature of the latter.

Mean Interatomic Distances for ZNEN1, ZNEN4, and Rehydrated ZNEN1

mean interatomic distance/Å ZNEN1 ZNEN4 rehydrated ZNEN1 ZnO−O(H) 2.066(7) 2.068(17) 2.084(15) ZnO−O(SO3) 2.363(4) 2.360(7) 2.361(9) ZnT−O 1.959(3) 1.957(9) 1.961(7) ZnT−N 1.980(15) 2.0 24(9) 2.046(18) N−C (disordered) 1.418(17) 1.448(15) 1.438(19) N−C (ordered) 1.491(9) C−C (disordered) 1.532(19) 1.637(16) 1.50(2) C−C (ordered) 1.572(7) S−O 1.484(8) 1.479(10) 1.49(2)

The FTIR spectrum (Figure S2, Supporting Information) reveals characteristic C−H bending modes at 1460(w) and 1380(w) cm-1, which disappear when TGA and analytical data indicate that the organic pillars are lost. The hydroxide stretches are found at 3492(b) cm-1. The H2O-derived OH stretch overlaps with the amine N−H bands. The widths of the bands are consistent with hydrogen bonding involving the water and hydroxide units. The HOH bend is at 1620 cm-1. The SO4 bands are at 1150 cm-1 (asymmetric stretch), 1030 cm-1 (symmetric stretch), 670 cm-1 (bend), and 460 cm-1 (deformation).
elements.clean_text: The FTIR spectrum (Figure S2, Supporting Information) reveals characteristic C-H bending modes at 1460(w) and 1380(w) cm-1, which disappear when TGA and analytical data indicate that the organic pillars are lost. The hydroxide stretches are found at 3492(b) cm-1. The H2O-derived OH stretch overlaps with the amine N-H bands. The widths of the bands are consistent with hydrogen bonding involving the water and hydroxide units. The HOH bend is at 1620 cm-1. The SO4 bands are at 1150 cm-1 (asymmetric stretch), 1030 cm-1 (symmetric stretch), 670 cm-1 (bend), and 460 cm-1 (deformation).

elements.content: Thermal Properties of ZNEN1. Four major weight losses occurred on heating ZNEN1 as shown in Figure with the calculated percentage total weight losses shown in comparison with the theoretical figures in parentheses. These losses corresponded to the liberation of interlayer water, SO3 and en respectively as confirmed by the characteristic mass spectrums. The final stage of gradual weight loss by 800 °C led to ZnO as the final product.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Properties of ZNEN1. Four major weight losses occurred on heating ZNEN1 as shown in Figure  with the calculated percentage total weight losses shown in comparison with the theoretical figures in parentheses. These losses corresponded to the liberation of interlayer water, SO3 and en respectively as confirmed by the characteristic mass spectrums. The final stage of gradual weight loss by 800 °C led to ZnO as the final product.

elements.content: TGA curve showing the sequence of liberated species on heating ZNEN1 with dotted lines representing each stage of weight losses. The asterisk indicates the intermediate step in the first weight loss due to water.
elements.clean_text: 4  TGA curve showing the sequence of liberated species on heating ZNEN1 with dotted lines representing each stage of weight losses. The asterisk indicates the intermediate step in the first weight loss due to water.

elements.content: The difference of the weight change from the expected figure of 9.3% upon complete water loss in the first step indicated by an asterisk in Figure is due to the partial loss of water before the experiment commenced. This corresponds to 46.7% of the interlayer water at 28 °C.
elements.clean_text: The difference of the weight change from the expected figure of 9.3% upon complete water loss in the first step indicated by an asterisk in Figure  is due to the partial loss of water before the experiment commenced. This corresponds to 46.7% of the interlayer water at 28 °C.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of ZNEN1 collected in situ and the monitoring of the most intense 00l reflections up to 200 °C showed a decrease in the interlayer spacing on dehydration (Figure ). The patterns collected up to 120 °C (Figure a) retained all the hkl reflections, but with a few additional very weak peaks, and different relative intensities for typical reflections, e.g., 101̄, 002, 003, 112, and 103̄ compared to those of the pristine phase. The interlayer spacing (Figure b) decreased slightly on further heating to 140 °C and dropped drastically from 10.5686(11) Å at 140 °C to 9.4993(6) Å and finally to 9.4896(7) Å at 160 and 180 °C, respectively. The intralayer repeat, on the other hand, slightly increased on the loss of the intergallery water. ZnO first became visible in the pattern at 180 °C (dotted line in Figure a), indicating that the ZNEN1 structure starts decomposing at this temperature. At higher temperatures, the ZnO phase becomes more pronounced. Complete loss of the SO3 unit occurred at 380 °C suggested by the TG/DTA-MS results, when the powder X-ray diffraction pattern at this temperature (Figure a) shows the complete collapse of the framework.
elements.clean_text: The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of ZNEN1 collected in situ and the monitoring of the most intense 00l reflections up to 200 °C showed a decrease in the interlayer spacing on dehydration (Figure ). The patterns collected up to 120 °C (Figure a) retained all the hkl reflections, but with a few additional very weak peaks, and different relative intensities for typical reflections, e.g., 101̄, 002, 003, 112, and 103̄ compared to those of the pristine phase. The interlayer spacing (Figure b) decreased slightly on further heating to 140 °C and dropped drastically from 10.5686(11) Å at 140 °C to 9.4993(6) Å and finally to 9.4896(7) Å at 160 and 180 °C, respectively. The intralayer repeat, on the other hand, slightly increased on the loss of the intergallery water. ZnO first became visible in the pattern at 180 °C (dotted line in Figure a), indicating that the ZNEN1 structure starts decomposing at this temperature. At higher temperatures, the ZnO phase becomes more pronounced. Complete loss of the SO3 unit occurred at 380 °C suggested by the TG/DTA-MS results, when the powder X-ray diffraction pattern at this temperature (Figure a) shows the complete collapse of the framework.

elements.content: (a) In situ powder X-ray diffraction patterns collected at various temperatures for ZNEN1, with dotted lines indicating the reflections attributed to ZnO and (b) variation of interlayer spacing (d) and in-plane a parameter as a function of temperature.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) In situ powder X-ray diffraction patterns collected at various temperatures for ZNEN1, with dotted lines indicating the reflections attributed to ZnO and (b) variation of interlayer spacing (d) and in-plane a parameter as a function of temperature.

elements.content: Dehydration − Rehydration Reaction for ZNEN1. The weight change of the ZNEN1 sample upon dehydration and subsequent rehydration (Figure S3, Supporting Information) shows that the reactions are reversible. Although the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the rehydrated phase (Figure S4, Supporting Information) can be indexed in P3̄ with refined parameters a = 8.3323(12), c = 10.6128(13), and V = 638.10(18) Å3, which are in good agreement with those of the pristine phase, the relative intensities of the reflections change considerably, compared with pristine ZNEN1. Those corresponding to 00l are lowered in intensity relative to other peaks causing the difference in relative intensities between the collected pattern and the patterns of both simulated data and the pristine ZNEN1. This can be due to some alteration in the structure of the bulk sample upon guest resorption or the preferred orientation, which is often found in the diffraction pattern of this type of materials. Reflections corresponding to ZnO observed in in situ X-ray diffraction experiments, in which the sample decomposed slightly after exposure at 180 °C for several hours, were not seen in the dehydration−rehydration experiment due to the short dwell (30 min) at 190 °C.
elements.clean_text: Dehydration - Rehydration Reaction for ZNEN1. The weight change of the ZNEN1 sample upon dehydration and subsequent rehydration (Figure S3, Supporting Information) shows that the reactions are reversible. Although the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the rehydrated phase (Figure S4, Supporting Information) can be indexed in P3̄ with refined parameters a = 8.3323(12), c = 10.6128(13), and V = 638.10(18) Å3, which are in good agreement with those of the pristine phase, the relative intensities of the reflections change considerably, compared with pristine ZNEN1. Those corresponding to 00l are lowered in intensity relative to other peaks causing the difference in relative intensities between the collected pattern and the patterns of both simulated data and the pristine ZNEN1. This can be due to some alteration in the structure of the bulk sample upon guest resorption or the preferred orientation, which is often found in the diffraction pattern of this type of materials. Reflections corresponding to ZnO observed in in situ X-ray diffraction experiments, in which the sample decomposed slightly after exposure at 180 °C for several hours, were not seen in the dehydration-rehydration experiment due to the short dwell (30 min) at 190 °C.

elements.content: Single - Crystal Structure of Rehydrated ZNEN1. The summary of the crystallographic details derived from the low temperature data (150(2) K) for rehydrated ZNEN1 is shown in Table , with the mean bond lengths in Table compared with the other phases. The framework structure was solved and refined based on the pristine ZNEN1 structure. The refined atomic coordinates and the equivalent isotropic thermal parameters are summarized in Table S4 (Supporting Information) and Figure b. The intergallery water was modeled with one fully occupied site, or three one-third occupied sites resulting in slightly larger R indices and higher thermal parameters for the former model with only one water molecule. The R w (all data) for the single site and disordered water models are 0.2289 and 0.2160, respectively, so the disordered model was employed for further analysis. Attempts to locate the disordered water oxygen atoms in the same positions as the pristine phase led to higher R factors (0.2371), and hence these disordered positions were located from electron density map directly.
elements.clean_text: Single - Crystal Structure of Rehydrated ZNEN1. The summary of the crystallographic details derived from the low temperature data (150(2) K) for rehydrated ZNEN1 is shown in Table , with the mean bond lengths in Table  compared with the other phases. The framework structure was solved and refined based on the pristine ZNEN1 structure. The refined atomic coordinates and the equivalent isotropic thermal parameters are summarized in Table S4 (Supporting Information) and Figure b. The intergallery water was modeled with one fully occupied site, or three one-third occupied sites resulting in slightly larger R indices and higher thermal parameters for the former model with only one water molecule. The R w (all data) for the single site and disordered water models are 0.2289 and 0.2160, respectively, so the disordered model was employed for further analysis. Attempts to locate the disordered water oxygen atoms in the same positions as the pristine phase led to higher R factors (0.2371), and hence these disordered positions were located from electron density map directly.

elements.content: Structural Description of ZNEN4 as the Supercell of ZNEN1. Although the structure of ZNEN4 is based on that of ZNEN1, a cell expansion in the xy plane is observed. This is due to positional long-range ordering of guest and pillar units, which are disordered in ZNEN1. Figure shows a relation between the supercell and subcell as a projection in the xy plane, and also the two distinct types of en molecules present in ZNEN4.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

 Structural Description of ZNEN4 as the Supercell of ZNEN1. Although the structure of ZNEN4 is based on that of ZNEN1, a cell expansion in the xy plane  is observed. This is due to positional long-range ordering of guest and pillar units, which are disordered in ZNEN1. Figure  shows a relation between the supercell and subcell as a projection in the xy plane, and also the two distinct types of en molecules present in ZNEN4.

elements.content: (a) The unit cell of ZNEN4 (solid line) as a supercell of ZNEN1 (dotted line) witha‘ = a when a‘ and a denote parameters for supercell and subcell, respectively. 1, 2, 3, and 4 represent the four different types of cavities, and (b) diagram shows intergallery water molecules occupying different types of cavities.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) The unit cell of ZNEN4 (solid line) as a supercell of ZNEN1 (dotted line) witha‘ =   a when a‘ and a denote parameters for supercell and subcell, respectively. 1, 2, 3, and 4 represent the four different types of cavities, and (b) diagram shows intergallery water molecules occupying different types of cavities.

elements.content: The arrangement of the sulfate groups in ZNEN4 is also different from that found in ZNEN1 reflecting the extensive hydrogen bonding between the components of the structure and the influence of this network on their mutual orientation. The orientations of the S(1)O4 and S(2)O4 units are slightly different (5.94(2)°) about the c axis as demonstrated by their torsion angles relative to S(3) (Figure ); O(10)−O(5)−O(4)‘−O(4) −2.79(2)° and O(4)−O(4)*−O(7)−O(9) −3.15(1)° for S(1) and S(2), respectively. The different orientations of the two sulfate groups on general positions arise from the different types of neighboring en; S(1) is surrounded by one disordered and two ordered pillars, whereas S(2) is surrounded only by ordered en. The observations suggest a correlation between the sulfate orientations and any disorder of the neighboring organic pillars. These differences in the xy plane lead to the cell expansion in ZNEN4 from ZNEN1.
elements.clean_text: The arrangement of the sulfate groups in ZNEN4 is also different from that found in ZNEN1 reflecting the extensive hydrogen bonding between the components of the structure and the influence of this network on their mutual orientation. The orientations of the S(1)O4 and S(2)O4 units are slightly different (5.94(2)°) about the c axis as demonstrated by their torsion angles relative to S(3) (Figure ); O(10)-O(5)-O(4)‘-O(4) -2.79(2)° and O(4)-O(4)*-O(7)-O(9) -3.15(1)° for S(1) and S(2), respectively. The different orientations of the two sulfate groups on general positions arise from the different types of neighboring en; S(1) is surrounded by one disordered and two ordered pillars, whereas S(2) is surrounded only by ordered en. The observations suggest a correlation between the sulfate orientations and any disorder of the neighboring organic pillars. These differences in the xy plane lead to the cell expansion in ZNEN4 from ZNEN1.

elements.content: Diagram showing relative basal orientations of different sulfate anions (dark gray solid triangle) attached to the same layer of corner-sharing octahedral ZnO6 (light gray dotted octahedra).
elements.clean_text: 7  Diagram showing relative basal orientations of different sulfate anions (dark gray solid triangle) attached to the same layer of corner-sharing octahedral ZnO6 (light gray dotted octahedra).

elements.content: Four distinct types of cavities are found in the supercell structure of ZNEN4 according to the different pillar environments, the horizontal interpillar distances, and the sulfate pendants. Type 1 and 4 (Figure a) are composed solely of ordered en molecules, whereas type 2 and 3 are surrounded by three ordered and one disordered organic pillar located in the cell corner. The shortest free dimensions are summarized in Table . It should be noted that the shortest distances are not solely between carbon atoms due to the distinct orientations of the ordered pillars resulting in the shorter distances between two neighboring nitrogen atoms or nitrogen and carbon atoms in some cases. The vertical free-opening dimension for each of the en pillared layered compounds in this family, CSEN (1.9 Å), ZNEN1 (2.0 Å), and ZNEN4 (1.9−2.0 Å), on the other hand, is found to be similar, indicating that the organic pillaring agent determines the size of the cavity opening. The corresponding solvent accessible volume (PLATON software) for ZNEN4 is 17.7% (664.6 Å3/ unit cell volume 3752.46 Å3) compared 15.1% calculated for ZNEN1.
elements.clean_text: Four distinct types of cavities are found in the supercell structure of ZNEN4 according to the different pillar environments, the horizontal interpillar distances, and the sulfate pendants. Type 1 and 4 (Figure a) are composed solely of ordered en molecules, whereas type 2 and 3 are surrounded by three ordered and one disordered organic pillar located in the cell corner. The shortest free dimensions are summarized in Table . It should be noted that the shortest distances are not solely between carbon atoms due to the distinct orientations of the ordered pillars resulting in the shorter distances between two neighboring nitrogen atoms or nitrogen and carbon atoms in some cases. The vertical free-opening dimension for each of the en pillared layered compounds in this family, CSEN (1.9 Å), ZNEN1 (2.0 Å), and ZNEN4 (1.9-2.0 Å), on the other hand, is found to be similar, indicating that the organic pillaring agent determines the size of the cavity opening. The corresponding solvent accessible volume (PLATON software) for ZNEN4 is 17.7% (664.6 Å3/ unit cell volume 3752.46 Å3) compared 15.1% calculated for ZNEN1.

elements.content:
Summary of the Shortest Interpillar Distances in Å, Types of Occupying Water Molecules and Sulfate Units for the Cavities of Type1, 2, 3, and 4 in Figure

cavity type measured atoms distance Å occupying water molecules occupying sulfates Type 1 N(3)H−N(6)H 2.74(5) O(25) S(2)O4 N(3)H−N(3)H 2.35(4) O(26) S(3)O4 N(3)H−N(3)H 2.35(4) O(27) N(3)H−N(6)H 2.60(5) O(29) Type 2 N(3)H−N(6)H 2.60(5) O(28) S(1)O4 × 2 C(5)H−C(2)H 2.70(6) O(30) C(5)H−C(2)H 2.70(6) N(3)H−N(6)H 2.60(5) Type 3 C(5)H−C(2)H 2.70(6) O(25) S(1)O4 N(3)H−N(6)H 2.74(5) O(26) S(2)O4 N(3)H−N(3)H 2.35(4) O(28) C(5)H−C(2)H 2.70(6) O(30) Type 4 (N(3)H−N(3)H) × 2 2.35(4) O(25) S(2)O4 × 2 (C(5)H−C(2)H) × 2 2.70(6) O(26) O(27)

The interlayer void is occupied by guest water molecules depicted in Figure b. The H2O/framework ratios of ZNEN4 and ZNEN1 differ. Rather than three one-third occupied sites as found in the subcell of ZNEN1, there are six different fully occupied sites for the intergallery water molecules in the ZNEN4 framework, all of which are ordered. In the ZNEN1 structure, the water molecules are disordered within the pore, but in some positions are close enough to the en to form hydrogen bonds with them. The water molecules in ZNEN4, on the other hand, are engaged in hydrogen bonding contact with each other (intraguest hydrogen bonds, Table ), suggesting a high degree of organization among the solvent water in ZNEN4.
elements.clean_text: The interlayer void is occupied by guest water molecules depicted in Figure b. The H2O/framework ratios of ZNEN4 and ZNEN1 differ. Rather than three one-third occupied sites as found in the subcell of ZNEN1, there are six different fully occupied sites for the intergallery water molecules in the ZNEN4 framework, all of which are ordered. In the ZNEN1 structure, the water molecules are disordered within the pore, but in some positions are close enough to the en to form hydrogen bonds with them. The water molecules in ZNEN4, on the other hand, are engaged in hydrogen bonding contact with each other (intraguest hydrogen  bonds, Table ), suggesting a high degree of organization among the solvent water in ZNEN4.

Summary of Hydrogen Bonds in ZNEN4 a

a  The intergallery water molecules with smaller thermal parameters are in bold and those with larger thermal parameters are in italic.

The thermal parameters of these intergallery water molecules in ZNEN4 may also be divided into two groups. The first group has small thermal parameters and includes mutually hydrogen bonding O(25), O(26), and O(27), whereas O(28), O(29), and O(30), which have fewer hydrogen bonding contacts to each other and are thus less organized, are in the second group with larger thermal parameters. The difference in thermal parameters also shows a correlation with both the type of cavities the water molecules occupy (Table ) and the hydrogen bonding to the en surrounding the cavities. The disordered en molecules form hydrogen bonds with O(28) (cavities of type 2 and 3 in Figure b), the intergallery water molecule with the largest thermal parameters, suggesting that the disorder in this en is correlated with that of the bound water molecules. The other en pillars form a well-defined hydrogen-bonding network with well-organized water (O(25), O(26), O(27) pillar−guest interactions, Table ). It is worth noting that the hydrogen bonds involving the disordered pillars (N(1)···O(28)) are longer than the corresponding ones found to the ordered en molecules. This distinction between water bound to ordered and to disordered en indicates a strong influence of hydrogen bonds on the order−disorder features of the interacting species.
elements.clean_text: The thermal parameters of these intergallery water molecules in ZNEN4 may also be divided into two groups. The first group has small thermal parameters and includes mutually hydrogen bonding O(25), O(26), and O(27), whereas O(28), O(29), and O(30), which have fewer hydrogen bonding contacts to each other and are thus less organized, are in the second group with larger thermal parameters. The difference in thermal parameters also shows a correlation with both the type of cavities the water molecules occupy (Table ) and the hydrogen bonding to the en surrounding the cavities. The disordered en molecules form hydrogen bonds with O(28) (cavities of type 2 and 3 in Figure b), the intergallery water molecule with the largest thermal parameters, suggesting that the disorder in this en is correlated with that of the bound water molecules. The other en pillars form a well-defined hydrogen-bonding network with well-organized water (O(25), O(26), O(27) pillar-guest interactions, Table ). It is worth noting that the hydrogen bonds involving the disordered pillars (N(1)⋅⋅⋅O(28)) are longer than the corresponding ones found to the ordered en molecules. This distinction between water bound to ordered and to disordered en indicates a strong influence of hydrogen bonds on the order-disorder features of the interacting species.

elements.content: There are also hydrogen bonds formed between the framework hydroxides and the sulfate pendants (intrahost contacts), as well as the solvent water (host−guest interactions, Table ). The basal oxygen atoms of every sulfate anion form extensive hydrogen bonds with the neighboring framework hydroxides. The orientation of the sulfate pendants is, consequently, mutually correlated with the hydrogen bonding of hydroxides, which also form hydrogen bonds with the solvent water molecules. The hydrogen-bonding network established between the sulfate, hydroxide, water, and the en pillars as described plays a crucial role in introducing a strong correlation between the orientation of these motifs, and the alignment of successive layers.
elements.clean_text: There are also hydrogen bonds formed between the framework hydroxides and the sulfate pendants (intrahost contacts), as well as the solvent water (host-guest interactions, Table ). The basal oxygen atoms of every sulfate anion form extensive hydrogen bonds with the neighboring framework hydroxides. The orientation of the sulfate pendants is, consequently, mutually correlated with the hydrogen bonding of hydroxides, which also form hydrogen bonds with the solvent water molecules. The hydrogen-bonding network established between the sulfate, hydroxide, water, and the en pillars as described plays a crucial role in introducing a strong correlation between the orientation of these motifs, and the alignment of successive layers.

elements.content: ZNEN1, ZNEN4, and Related Structures. ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 are topologically related to the synthetic basic zinc sulfates 3Zn(OH)2·ZnSO4·mH2O (m = 3 and 5)14 and the mineral Namuwite (Zn,Cu)4SO4(OH)6·4H2O15 with the cell dimensions notably similar to those of ZNEN1. Introduction of en pillars retains the AAA stacking layer arrangement but draws the layers closer to each other, resulting in less water residing in the void. ZNEN1, however, differs from the trihydrate phase of zinc sulfate although both phases contain the same amount of interlayer water. Two adjacent layers in the trihydrate zinc sulfate are displaced by 1/2[a+b] instead of being in registry, so the en pillars enforce the AAA stacking. ZNEN4, as a supercell of ZNEN1, due to the order−disorder features of en and the sulfate groups adopts a similar structure to the pentahydrate zinc sulfate and Namuwite cases.
elements.clean_text: ZNEN1, ZNEN4, and Related Structures. ZNEN1 and ZNEN4 are topologically related to the synthetic basic zinc sulfates 3Zn(OH)2⋅ZnSO4⋅mH2O (m = 3 and 5)14 and the mineral Namuwite (Zn,Cu)4SO4(OH)6⋅4H2O15 with the cell dimensions notably similar to those of ZNEN1. Introduction of en pillars retains the AAA stacking layer arrangement but draws the layers closer to each other, resulting in less water residing in the void. ZNEN1, however, differs from the trihydrate phase of zinc sulfate although both phases contain the same amount of interlayer water. Two adjacent layers in the trihydrate zinc sulfate are displaced by 1/2[a+b] instead of being in registry, so the en pillars enforce the AAA stacking. ZNEN4, as a supercell of ZNEN1, due to the order-disorder features of en and the sulfate groups adopts a similar structure to the pentahydrate zinc sulfate and Namuwite cases.

elements.content: Thermal Decomposition of ZNEN1. ZNEN1 shows the same sequence of liberated species on heating as CSEN; the manner of thermal decomposition of these materials is, however, substantially different. The fully dehydrated phase of ZNEN1 is obtained at a much lower temperature, and rather than an abrupt decrease of the interlayer spacing on loss of water, the interlayer distance of ZNEN1 gradually reduces on dehydration. The presence of ZnO at 180 °C implies the onset of framework decomposition. ZNEN1 is hence less thermally robust than CSEN. The complete collapse of the ZNEN1 framework is due to the loss of the sulfate pendants, showing the importance of the sulfate groups in stabilizing the structure. By losing the sulfate and thus initiating the framework decomposition, the interlayer spacing of ZNEN1 reduces drastically. The structure of ZNEN1 collapses completely as all the sulfate is lost at 380 °C.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Decomposition of ZNEN1. ZNEN1 shows the same sequence of liberated species on heating as CSEN; the manner of thermal decomposition of these materials is, however, substantially different. The fully dehydrated phase of ZNEN1 is obtained at a much lower temperature, and rather than an abrupt decrease of the interlayer spacing on loss of water, the interlayer distance of ZNEN1 gradually reduces on dehydration. The presence of ZnO at 180 °C implies the onset of framework decomposition. ZNEN1 is hence less thermally robust than CSEN. The complete collapse of the ZNEN1 framework is due to the loss of the sulfate pendants, showing the importance of the sulfate groups in stabilizing the structure. By losing the sulfate and thus initiating the framework decomposition, the interlayer spacing of ZNEN1 reduces drastically. The structure of ZNEN1 collapses completely as all the sulfate is lost at 380 °C.

elements.content: The Structure of Rehydrated ZNEN1. The framework structure of ZNEN1 was retained under the dehydration−rehydration process confirmed by (Table S4, Supporting Information) the close similarities in channel opening size, solvent accessible volume, the bond lengths, and angles (Table ) of the rehydrated phase to the pristine phase. Although the numbers of the water of crystallization in both as-synthesized and rehydrated phases are the same, the distribution of these water molecules within the interlayer spacing however slightly differs. Rather than occupying sites close to the pore center, as in as-synthesized ZNEN1, the disordered water in the rehydrated structure are closer to each other and the basal corners of the sulfate groups allowing hydrogen bonds to be formed to both the framework and the en pillars (Figure S1, Supporting Information). It can be noticed that every site of the disordered water in the rehydrated phase is in hydrogen bonding contact with the en pillars, which is not the case for as-synthesized ZNEN1. The differing water positions in the rehydrated material indicate that the process is not microscopically reversible, and suggests that the initial geometry of the pillars can direct the guests to locations other than those in which they occupy when acting as a template or space filler for the layered phases to grow around.
elements.clean_text: The Structure of Rehydrated ZNEN1. The framework structure of ZNEN1 was retained under the dehydration-rehydration process confirmed by (Table S4, Supporting Information) the close similarities in channel opening size, solvent accessible volume, the bond lengths, and angles (Table ) of the rehydrated phase to the pristine phase. Although the numbers of the water of crystallization in both as-synthesized and rehydrated phases are the same, the distribution of these water molecules within the interlayer spacing however slightly differs. Rather than occupying sites close to the pore center, as in as-synthesized ZNEN1, the disordered water in the rehydrated structure are closer to each other and the basal corners of the sulfate groups allowing hydrogen bonds to be formed to both the framework and the en pillars (Figure S1, Supporting  Information). It can be noticed that every site of the disordered water in the rehydrated phase is in hydrogen bonding contact with the en pillars, which is not the case for as-synthesized ZNEN1. The differing water positions in the rehydrated material indicate that the process is not microscopically reversible, and suggests that the initial geometry of the pillars can direct the guests to locations other than those in which they occupy when acting as a template or space filler for the layered phases to grow around.

elements.content: The detailed structural responses of porous organic−inorganic hybrid phases, such as the pillared phases discussed here, to the guest distribution, desorption, and resorption is of importance for any applications of these currently topical phases. The static or dynamic disorder of these motifs can strongly alter the guest environment. The contrast between the subcell phase ZNEN1 and supercell ZNEN4 phases illustrates this point directly.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The detailed structural responses of porous organic-inorganic hybrid phases, such as the pillared phases discussed here, to the guest distribution, desorption, and resorption is of importance for any applications of these currently topical phases. The static or dynamic disorder of these motifs can strongly alter the guest environment. The contrast between the subcell phase ZNEN1 and supercell ZNEN4 phases illustrates this point directly.

elements.content: Refined atomic coordinates and equivalent thermal parameters for ZNEN1 and ZNEN4; list of interatomic distances; summary of hydrogen bonds in CSEN, ZNEN1, and rehydrated ZNEN1; FTIR spectrum of ZNEN1 in Nujol and fluorolube mulls; TGA curve of ZNEN1; CIF files of ZNEN1, ZNEN4, and rehydrated ZNEN1. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org

cln_elements.content: Thermal Properties of ZNEN1. Four major weight losses occurred on heating ZNEN1 as shown in Figure with the calculated percentage total weight losses shown in comparison with the theoretical figures in parentheses. These losses corresponded to the liberation of interlayer water, SO3 and en respectively as confirmed by the characteristic mass spectrums. The final stage of gradual weight loss by 800 °C led to ZnO as the final product.

These losses corresponded to the liberation of interlayer water, SO3 and en respectively as confirmed by the characteristic mass spectrums. The final stage of gradual weight loss by 800 °C led to ZnO as the final product.
